citation.abstract:
To assess the effect of age and gender on the pharmacokinetics (PK) of the ghrelin receptor agonist anamorelin.
Three demographic cohorts of healthy subjects were enrolled in this single-center, open-label study. Subjects received a single oral dose (25 mg) of anamorelin HCl. Serial blood samples were collected over 24 hours to assess anamorelin PK and circulating growth hormone (GH) levels. Data were compared with a reference cohort.
Anamorelin was rapidly absorbed in all cohorts; peak concentrations were observed 30-45 minutes and 2-4 hours post-dose, which declined biexponentially with mean terminal half-lives of 6-7 hours. An age effect on Cmax and AUC∞ was not apparent; however, mean AUC∞ values were approximately 1.8-1.9-fold higher in the female cohorts than in the reference male cohort. GH increase was rapid and virtually identical in both sexes, though attenuated in elderly subjects. No clinically significant safety or tolerability findings were observed.
While PK parameters do suggest higher exposure in females, this effect is considered to be modest given the variability of the 6-8 subjects per cohort. Moreover, no such effect was observed in the pharmacodynamic responses, thus, dose adjustment for age and gender is considered unnecessary.
citation.title: An open‐label clinical trial of the effects of age and gender on the pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics and safety of the ghrelin receptor agonist anamorelin

wikipedia.title: Anamorelin
wikipedia.summary: Anamorelin (INN) (developmental code names ONO-7643, RC-1291, ST-1291), also known as anamorelin hydrochloride (USAN, JAN), is a non-peptidic, orally-active, selective agonist of the ghrelin/growth hormone secretagogue receptor (GHSR) with appetite-enhanci
